title: How the rich invest: Bingo Industries' Daniel Tartak closes in on $200m
text:
It's the stock rubbishing the short sellers.

Waste management group Bingo Industries has become a favourite of the short sellers over the past few months. But, to their dismay, it has proved resilient. In the past year Bingo shares have rallied nearly 50 per cent. Over the same time the short position in the stock has built from 1.8 per cent to 8.6 per cent, with the short position gathering pace over the past few months.

The price rally has helped boost the fortunes of Bingo's 33-year-old managing director Daniel Tartak, who made his debut on the Financial Review Young Rich List last year with an estimated worth of $130 million.

Bingo Industries chief executive Daniel Tartak has a long-term vision. Louie Douvis

The value of Tartak's 17 per cent shareholding is Bingo is now worth more than $191 million, which if the Young Rich List was calculated today would put him in 12th place.

From next week, Tartak can begin to cash in. Escrow arrangements put in place for the company's float last year, will cease when Bingo delivers its full-year results next Tuesday
description: Like fellow Young Rich Lister Nicholas Molnar, Bingo Industries CEO Daniel Tartak is taking it to the short sellers.
